projects.description: A random quote generator to practice iteration and basic JavaScript concepts. Quote and background are chosen at random via timer or button press.

Utilizes progress enchancement and unobtrusive JavaScript to create a user-friendly directory. Code works with any number of students to generate pages that display 10 at a time. Search bar actively filters students during typing.

Make sure you sign up for the JavaScript Conference! This project practices HTML form elements and associated JavaScript to create a friendly user-experience. Error messages will appear if any field is left blank upon submission, and radio buttons will disable competing time slots to ensure users will not sign up for overlapping programs.
'Hangman'-inspired web game that utilizes object-oriented JavaScript. Try to guess the phrase with fewer than 5 missed letters! Phrase is randomly generated each game from a local array.

Uses a public random personnel generator API to create a mock employee directory. When clicked, a modal window with additional information will display. Search bar filters displayed employees upon submission.

Want to grab the latest images from flickr? This app has 3 pre-set options for searches along with a search bar for whatever else the user wants. 24 images are returned and displayed in a photo gallery with some basic CSS animations.
Using Express, SQLite, and Sequelize, this project creates a simple web interface that allows the user to create, view, update, and delete books from a database.

Using Express, the project is a RESTful API that employs basic security (via a Basic Auth header and hashing passwords before saving user data) to manage a course-rating application and user creation/ info retrieval.

Using a MERN stack, my final project is a fully developed (front- and back-end) site that allows users to grab quick information (travel data, weather, places of interest, and food) for a given location. Basic security, authentication, and session practices are implemented to allow users to register/ sign in to use the app. I built a single-server proxy setup to run the React app, API that processes the data, and routes for handling user interactions such as logging in/ out, registering, and returning user data.
